name: THE APPRENTICESHIP COLLEGE LTD
marketingInfo:
The Apprenticeship College delivers apprenticeships that prepare people for the future. We believe whilst delivering apprenticeships we also deliver new skills that benefit both employer and employee.  

We deliver 'Levy compliant' apprenticeship standards as the backbone of the learning and development programmes to develop your workforce. We design courses that deliver new skills and unlock the potential of your existing staff through expert master-classes, workshops and immersive theatre based learning.  

Our programmes have commercial level training workshops, alongside group and 121 coaching of your apprentices. We run open courses in London, or deliver to your staff on site.

standards.marketingInfo:
The Apprenticeship College is a unique, purpose-built, apprenticeship training provider specialising in creating rewarding and stretching apprenticeships that are fit for purpose. That means that we specifically design apprenticeships that meet your needs as an employer, are fully apprenticeship levy compliant and enable your apprentices to achieve the qualifications and skills that you want them to have.

Key skills to be developed in this Apprenticeship Standard include creating and delivering operational plans, managing projects, leading and managing teams, managing change, financial and resource management, talent management, coaching and mentoring.  The programme is aimed at middle management in roles such as Regional/Departmental Manager, Operations Manager and Specialist Managers.

A team leader/supervisor is a first line management role, with operational/project responsibilities or responsibility for managing a team to deliver a clearly defined outcome. They provide direction, instructions and guidance to ensure the achievement of set goals. Working in the private, public or third sector and in all sizes of organisation, specific responsibilities will vary, but the knowledge, skills and behaviour's needed will be the same whatever the role. Key responsibilities are likely to include supporting, managing and developing team members, managing projects, planning and monitoring workloads and resources, delivering operational plans, resolving problems, and building relationships internally and externally.

The role of a customer service practitioner is to deliver high quality products and services to the customers of their organisation. Your core responsibility will be to provide a high quality service to customers which will be delivered from the workplace, digitally, or through going out into the customer's own locality. These may be one-off or routine contacts and include dealing with orders, payments, offering advice, guidance and support, meet-and-greet, sales, fixing problems, after care, service recovery or gaining insight through measuring customer satisfaction.

Projects are defined and delivered within different contexts and across diverse industry sectors. Be they large or small in scale or scope, every project needs to be managed to ensure its success and that's the role of a Project Manager. Good project management means knowing what needs to be achieved, how it will be achieved, how long it will take as well as how much it will cost. Project management is a skilled profession and our Associate Project Management apprenticeship, accredited by the Association of Project Management, is designed to provide participants with the skills, knowledge and behaviour's that are needed to excel in this role.

Our programmes are delivered using technical workshops, theatre based learning and skills coaching.

Our Retailing and Retail Management apprenticeships are designed to be used in a wide variety of retailing contexts: large high street fashion retail and small boutiques as well as department stores and, increasingly, online retail hubs.

Each apprenticeship comprises a series of masterclasses, taught workshops, and theatre based learning experiences that are further supported by a programme of skills coaching and mentoring.

We are able to individualise our programmes to meet your needs; be that training priorities, logistics of delivery (managing within peak times plus 24/7 & weekend functions) and embedding your core values/customer commitments.

We offer apprenticeships for 'shop floor', team leaders and retail managers.

Our Retailing and Retail Management apprenticeships are designed to be used in a wide variety of retailing contexts: large high street fashion retail and small boutiques as well as department stores and, increasingly, online retail hubs.

Each apprenticeship comprises a series of masterclasses, taught workshops, and theatre based learning experiences that are further supported by a programme of skills coaching and mentoring.

We are able to individualise our programmes to meet your needs; be that training priorities, logistics of delivery (managing within peak times plus 24/7 & weekend functions) and embedding your core values/customer commitments.

We offer apprenticeships for 'shop floor', team leaders and retail managers.

Business administrators have a highly transferable set of knowledge, skills and behaviour's that can be applied in all sectors. This includes small and large businesses alike; from the public sector, private sector and charitable sector. The role may involve working independently or as part of a team and will involve developing, implementing, maintaining and improving administrative services. Business administrators develop key skills and behaviour's to support their own progression towards management responsibilities.

Our programme is equally applicable to newly employed Apprentices, and training of current Administrators. The course is a mixture of technical workshops, IT workshops, Theatre Based Learning sessions and Skills Coaching.

In line with all our other programmes we use a blend of masterclasses, workshops, theatre based learning and skills coaching to deliver this Apprenticeship. We will individualise the programme to meet your needs; be that training priorities, logistics of delivery (managing peak periods, 24/7 & weekend operations) and meeting company values.

### What apprentices will learn

*   Meeting deadlines to ensure the supply chain is running efficiently and managing unexpected demand
*   Helping with everyday problem solving activities where small process improvements can have a significant improvement on the rest of the supply chain
*   Forecasting customer demand

Projects within this course will be set to deliver improvements on real KPIs set by the employer.

The Apprenticeship College delivers apprenticeship training with a real commercial focus, with knowledge sessions being a mixture of masterclasses, workshops and theatre based learning. Alongside this each learner has a dedicated Skills Coach who supports on a 121 basis in the workplace. Ordinarily training is 1 day per month with project/knowledge assignments and workbased coaching in between these sessions.

Improvement Practitioners use a blend of Lean and Six Sigma, project and change management principles and tools to identify and lead the delivery of change across organisational functions and processes. Practitioners lead smaller projects - tackling issues that may require swift problem solving, or re-occurring challenges that require in-depth analysis.

The Apprenticeship College deliver apprenticeship training with a real commercial focus, the training being a mixture of masterclasses, technical workshops and theatre based learning. All learners have a dedicated Skills Coach who supports them on a 121 basis within the workplace. Typically the training is 1 day per month, with project/assignment work in between with workbased coaching.

Improvement Technicians are responsible for delivery and coaching of improvement activity within an area of responsibility, often associated with Lean and Six Sigma methodologies. Typically, Technicians work as a member of an operational team to resolve problems - preventing re-occurrence, engaging others in issues affecting them and to support the improvement of performance.

The main purpose of a customer service specialist is to be a 'professional' for direct customer support within all sectors and organisation types.

Those on programme are described as - You are an advocate of Customer Service who acts as a referral point for dealing with more complex or technical customer requests, complaints, and queries. You are often an escalation point for complicated or ongoing customer problems. As an expert in your organisation's products and/or services, you share knowledge with your wider team and colleagues.

Completion of this apprenticeship will lead to eligibility to join the Institute of Customer Service as an Individual member at Professional level.

The Apprenticeship College is a unique, purpose-built, apprenticeship training provider specialising in creating rewarding and stretching apprenticeships that are fit for purpose. That means that we specifically design apprenticeships that meet your needs as an employer, are fully apprenticeship levy compliant and enable your people to achieve the qualifications and skills that you want them to have.

Key skills to be developed in this Apprenticeship Standard include planning sales activities, lead the end-to-end sales & manage sales internally. Retaining/growing a number of existing customers, generating new business by contacting prospective customers, qualifying opportunities & bringing the sales process to a mutually acceptable close.

The role of a coach is to support in building the self-belief of others, better equipping individuals to collaborate, innovate, deal with the increasing pace of change and get the best from diverse environments. Coaching helps employees to better perform, develop capabilities and empower individuals to achieve their potential.

Understanding commitment to self-development, enabling insight and learning, outcome and action, use of models and techniques and evaluation are overarching areas which feature within the coaching apprenticeship.

This programme is suitable for people already managing/coaching people and wanting to improve their skills, or those who have an ambition to coach in a professional context.

name: THE OLDHAM COLLEGE
marketingInfo:
Oldham College is based in Greater Manchester and has a long established track record of delivering apprenticeships.

We offer a broad range of apprenticeships combining the high quality college training facilities with occupational specialist assessors, in priority sectors including: Construction, Health & Social Care, Business and Professional, Art and Design, Retail and Commercial.

In addition to the established apprenticeships, we are further developing our higher level offer in partnership with University Campus Oldham to extend the opportunities at Level 4 and above.

Our extended service to employers includes support with identifying company training needs and access to grants, and recruitment support via the college Job Shop.

standards.marketingInfo:
*   Higher Apprenticeship Standard - Network Engineer
*   Our staff are leading experts in the delivery of IT Apprenticeships with over 20yrs industry experience and are fully up to date with industry practices. A Network Engineer Apprentice will develop skills and knowledge to design, install, maintain and support communication networks within an organisation or between organisations.
*   We are a CISCO Academy able to offer Vendor qualifications.
*   State of the art facilities and equipment in our dedicated Digital and Creative building.
*   1-2-1 supported sessions embed training, assessment and skills building to maximise the development of knowledge and skills of individuals.
*   E-portfolio access allowing learners and employers to track and monitor progress

### Advanced Apprenticeship Standard - Electrotechnical

*   We are now delivering the new Electrotechnical Standard, designed by employers and recognised by industry.
*   Taught by specialists in our up to date training facilities, learners are supported and observed in the workplace by qualified assessors with a wealth of expertise in the industry.
*   On successful completion, the Apprentice can apply to be recognised by the Institute of Engineering and Technology (IET) as an Engineering Technician. This will enable them to have professional recognition and adopt (EngTech) in their title.
*   The apprentice will be issued with the appropriate Electrotechnical Certification Scheme (ECS) card and be able to apply for 'Electrician' status from the JIB.

Golf Greenkeeper is responsible for the maintenance, care and overall appearance of a golf course in line with employer's requirements. It is their job to maintain a good quality playing surface and ensure the course offers a consistent challenge and an enjoyable experience for golfers.

There are four key turf grass areas on a golf course - greens, tees, fairways and areas of rough, each of which requires a different type of maintenance. Using a range of equipment and machinery safely and competently will play a major part within an apprentices training programme. You will also be involved in hazard, environmental and ecological operations which may include bunker maintenance, planting turf, trees, shrubs and developing wildlife habitats.

*   Apprenticeship Standard - Property Maintenance Operative
*   The Property Maintenance standard is delivered in house in our specialist facilities and in the workplace by highly qualified vocational staff.
*   The qualification is a mix of practical hands on work, interactive theory classroom activities and on site evidence. Learners will study various practical maintenance techniques towards Plumbing, Electrical, Painting, Tiling and Carpentry and be taught health and safety, sustainability and customer service amongst other things.
*   The NVQ portfolio supports work towards the technical certificate.
*   Learners also complete their English and maths qualifications and use Moodle and IT.
*   Progression from this course could be onto the level 3 programme

*   Advanced Apprenticeship Standard - Public Services Officer
*   This standard will develop apprentice's knowledge, skills, values and behaviours within front line public services environments.
*   Delivery method is on and off the job; 1 day per week in College, however we can be flexible for off site delivery.
*   The course is delivered by a qualified industry specialist with up to date knowledge and awareness of business practices, who works closely with employers and apprentices to develop and prepare the apprentice for end point assessment.
*   Bespoke milestone planners detail course content for the duration of the apprenticeship.
*   This course can be delivered internally to upskill existing staff or can be utilised to recruit new staff to roles within your business.

*   Advanced Apprenticeship Standard - Paralegal
*   This standard will develop apprentice's knowledge, skills and behaviours within a legal role/environment.
*   This qualification is delivered both on and off the job; a modern campus with fully equipped facilities and resources are available for apprentices to use.
*   The course is delivered by a qualified industry specialist with up to date knowledge and awareness of current legal practices, who works closely with employers and apprentices to develop and prepare the apprentice for end point assessment.
*   Bespoke milestone planners detail course content for the duration of the apprenticeship.
*   This course can be delivered internally to upskill existing staff or can be utilised to recruit new staff to roles within your business.

*   Advanced Apprenticeship Standard - Dental Nurse  
    Delivered by industry specialists using innovative teaching methods, and designed by dental professionals, this qualification provides learners with a comprehensive understanding of the knowledge and skills needed in order to become a GDC professionally registered dental nurse.
*   Throughout the qualification, learners will cover specialist topics that reflect all aspects of clinical responsibilities and duties of a dental nurse's role, enabling them to become high-quality practitioners in clinical environments.
*   On completion, learners are able to progress onto a higher level apprenticeship or degree.

The primary responsibility of a Unified Communications Trouble Shooter is to provide customers (internal or external) with a specialist technical service to set them up on unified communications systems and to resolve problems when they arise. This service can be delivered face-to-face, on the ‘phone or online. They are required to install equipment and software and handle incidents and requests for help, including providing fault diagnostic across a broad range of unified communications technologies in accordance with business service level agreements.

*   Advanced Apprenticeship Standard - Infrastructure Technician
*   Our staff are leading experts in the delivery of IT Apprenticeships with over 20yrs industry experience who are fully up to date with industry practices.
*   An Infrastructure Technician provides support helping customers when using technology, by using tools to problem solve and trouble shoot non routine problems.
*   The Infrastructure Technician sets people up on systems and provides support when they need it, rectifying issues to maintain the organisations IT Infrastructure.
*   We are a CISCO Academy able to offer Vendor qualifications.
*   State of the art facilities
*   1-2-1 supported sessions embed training, assessment and skills building to maximise the development of knowledge and skills.

Testers typically design and prepare test plans and conduct software testing as appropriate to ensure that software is fit for purpose, document and report results of testing activities and have a good understanding of the software life-cycle and software development practices.

Technical knowledge and understanding is assessed on programme through Ofqual-regulated Knowledge Modules.

The decision as to when an apprentice is ready to progress to the end point assessment phase (Gateway) will be made by the employer and the training provider based on their monitoring of apprentices' progress. In order to move into the end point assessment phase apprentices will need to have passed all the Knowledge Modules and be able to produce a portfolio.

Oldham College offers the highest quality of teaching delivered by a professional skilled team of trainers/assessors with extensive industry experience in the Legal industry.

*   Our training is structured to suit your business needs and aims to maximise your apprentice's development through relevant on the job training at your professional location and classroom based study.
*   We will provide your apprentice with pastoral support and a dedicated visiting assessor to carry out progress reviews and assessments in the form of written and practical tasks.
*   We offer access to online learning and apprentice tracking resources.
*   Our Business Teams will be on hand to offer full support for all your training and apprenticeship requirements.

The primary role of a Cyber Security Technologist is to apply an understanding of cyber threats, hazards, risks, controls, measures and mitigations to protect organisations systems and people. Those focused on the technical side work on areas such as security design & architecture, security testing, investigations & response. Those focussed on the risk analysis side focus on areas such as operations, risk, governance & compliance. Either pathway are required to achieve security outcomes in a legal and regulatory context in all parts of the economy. They develop and apply practical knowledge of information security to deliver solutions that fulfil an organisation’s requirements.

*   Apprenticeship Standard - Retailer
*   This qualification develops the role of those working to assist customers when they purchase products and services, it will enable the apprentice to demonstrate good product knowledge of the business product range, the ability to take payments, make recommendations on products and services, advise and deal with customers demonstrating excellent client care, maintaining stock levels and support financial performance.
*   Delivered by industry specialists your apprentice will have a bespoke milestone planner, which will support their journey, identify practical review points, 20% off the job, mock EPA and gateway meetings.
*   Opportunities for your apprentice to progress to level 3 Team leader Retailer.

*   Higher Apprenticeship Standard - Operations Management
*   This higher level standard will extend and build upon the apprentice's knowledge, skills and behaviours typically within a middle management role.
*   This qualification is delivered both on and off the job, at our University Campus site. However, delivery is flexible and can be tailored to suit business/apprentices needs.
*   Management specialists work closely with employers and apprentices to develop and prepare the apprentice for end point assessment.
*   Personalised milestone planners detail course content of all components for the duration of the apprenticeship.
*   This course can be delivered internally to upskill existing staff or can be utilised to recruit new staff to roles within your business.

*   Advanced Apprenticeship Standard - Team Leading
*   This standard will extend and build upon the apprentice's knowledge, skills and behaviours in a first line management role within all industry environments.
*   This qualification is delivered both on and off the job, at our fully resourced and modern University Campus site.
*   Delivery is flexible and can be tailored to suit business/apprentices needs.
*   Management specialists work closely with employers and apprentices to develop and prepare the apprentice for end point assessment.
*   Personalised milestone planners detail course content of all components for the duration of the apprenticeship.
*   This course can be delivered internally to upskill existing staff or utilised to recruit new staff within your business.

This apprenticeship provides the foundation knowledge, skills and experience for the role of Warehouse Operative.  
Warehouse Operatives communicate with a wide range of people and customers. They have a passion to meet customers' expectations by providing a quality service that encourages repeat business. Individuals in this role are highly competent in using industry-recognised systems and associated services (eg Traffic/Warehouse Management Systems) and will be able to work under pressure to tight deadlines.

This higher level standard will develop apprentice's knowledge, skills and behaviours within a senior accounting role such as managing budgets and drafting financial statements.

This qualification is delivered both on and off the job;.day release is 1 day per week.

Industry specialists with recent up to date knowledge and awareness of current accounting practises work closely with employers and apprentices to develop and prepare the apprentice for end point assessment.

This course can be delivered internally to up skill existing staff or can be utilised to recruit new staff to roles within your business.

Apprentices will develop a wide range of skills, which will help them to progress in their chosen career path.

Advanced Apprenticeship Standard - Lead Care Worker

*   Delivered by industry specialists and designed by experts in the health and social care field, this high level qualification aims to prepare learners to become senior level professionals in the health and social care environment.
*   Throughout the qualification, learners will cover a wide range of topics, as well as understand the varying roles that can be undertaken in a health & social care setting.
*   Learners are given the opportunity to select various optional units, such as end of life and dementia care with these being chosen based upon their job role.
*   On completion, learners are able to progress onto a higher level qualification.

Apprenticeship Standard - Adult Care Worker

*   Delivered by industry specialists and designed by experts in the health and social care field, this qualification develops the skills, knowledge and behaviour's needed when working with adults in the health and social care environment.
*   Throughout the qualification, learners will cover a wide range of topics, as well as understand the varying roles that can be undertaken in a health & social care setting.
*   Learners are given the opportunity to select various optional units, such as end of life and dementia care with these being chosen based upon their job role.
*   On completion, learners are able to progress onto a related Level 3 qualification.

This standard will develop apprentice's knowledge, skills and behaviours within a customer service role/environment.

This qualification is delivered both on and off the job; it is flexible and tailored to suit employer/apprentices needs.

Industry specialists with recent up to date knowledge and awareness of current business practices work closely with employers and apprentices to develop and prepare the apprentice for end point assessment.

This course can be delivered internally to upskill existing staff or can be utilised to recruit new staff to roles within your business.

Within the qualification, apprentices will develop a wide range of skills, which will help them to progress to the next level.

Advanced Apprenticeship Standard - Accountancy

*   This standard develops upon basic accountancy practice for apprentices.
*   Apprentices will gain further skills and knowledge in accounting.
*   This qualification is delivered on and off the job; day release is 1 day per week.
*   Personalised milestone planners detail course content for all aspects of the apprenticeship.
*   Industry specialists with recent knowledge and awareness of current practices work closely with employers and apprentices to develop and prepare the apprentice for end point assessment.
*   This course can be delivered internally to upskill existing staff and to recruit new staff.
*   Apprentices gain a range of skills, which will help them build a career path and naturally progress to a higher level course.

Apprenticeship Standard - Hair Professionals

Hairdressing

*   This qualification will develop the Hairdresser to deliver a range of services, shampooing, cutting hair using a range of techniques, styling and finishing hair, perming, colour and lightening women's and men's hair.

Barbering

*   This qualification will develop the Barber to deliver a range of services, shampooing, cut hair using a range of barbering techniques, style and finish hair, cut facial hair and provide shaving services.

These qualifications are delivered both on and off the job, it is flexible and can be tailored to suit.

They will gain core salon behaviours demonstrating health and safety, client care, teamwork and effective communication with colleagues and clients

Responsible for developing and creating content that can be used across a variety of media including digital, social media, broadcast or in print. Working to the customer/client brief, they research, prepare and develop the media messaging to maximise audience engagement, capturing the strategy and objectives of the brand and needs of the customer they are representing. They have to capture what is exciting about a campaign and design the elements that can be used across media platforms and channels. They can work in advertising, marketing or digital agencies, may progress into Content Creation/Development roles at more senior levels across the industry, including with digital agencies, broadcasters and publishers.

The apprentice must complete a portfolio of evidence that meets the requirements of the training specification and the apprenticeship standard. The training specification outlines the recommended content that needs to be covered during the apprenticeship programme to meet the skills, knowledge and behavioural requirements of the standard. The portfolio is mandatory and elements of it may be used to inform questioning during the professional discussion. Supporting evidence must be collected in all seasons of the final year to allow for the student to build their portfolio. The portfolio will not graded as part of the end point assessment, but will be the basis of the professional discussion.

With a focus on adding value,the role of business administrator contributes to the efficiency of an organisation, through support of functional areas, working across teams and resolving issues as requested.  
The business administrator is expected to deliver their responsibilities efficiently and with integrity - showing a positive attitude. The role involves demonstrating strong  
communication skills (both written and verbal) and adopting a proactive approach to developing skills. The business administrator is also expected to show initiative, managing  
priorities and own time, problem-solving skills, decision-making and the potential for people management responsibilities through mentoring or coaching others.
PLEASE COME BACK SOON FOR FURTHER INFORMATION!

School Business Professionals (SBPs) perform a role which is unique to schools, administering and managing the financial, site and support services within the school context. They provide essential support to school leadership teams, implementing their financial and business decisions

The occupation involves carrying out skilled work, primarily using timber products, either on a construction site, or in a workshop, creating and installing building components. An Architectural Joiner will normally be employed in a workshop producing timber based building components and other architectural products, such as doors, windows, units and staircases, which are then transported to construction sites to be installed by site carpenters. There will be opportunities within this qualification to take part in skills competitions. These include World skills and the Institute of carpenters competitions.

The advanced carpenter and joiner is able to undertake complex job tasks, requiring high levels of practical skills and knowledge, in addition to managing their own work and leading small teams. An Advanced Site Carpenter will normally work on a building site, or in domestic and commercial premises, preparing and installing complex and often bespoke building components e.g. high quality doors, shaped linings, staircases with turns, complex wall and floor units, erecting bespoke structural carpentry (inclined roofs and joists) and erecting complex roof structures (e.g. inclined roofs with hips, valleys and dormers).There will be opportunities within this qualification to take part in skills competitions.

Bricklayers lay bricks, blocks and other types of building components in mortar to construct and repair walls, foundations, partitions, arches and other structures eg chimney stacks. They might also refurbish brickwork and masonry on restoration projects. The range of sites and projects that bricklayers will work on include large commercial developments, new builds in housing, alterations, extensions and restorations. A bricklayer may work one-on-one or on larger jobs where their bricklaying group (gang) may work on a particular section of a building alongside other bricklaying gangs as well as other trades.

Typically 36 months on-programme working towards the Standard, with a minimum of 20% off-the-job training.The EPA should only start once the employer is satisfied that the apprentice is consistently working at or above the level set out in the standard, that the requirements for EPA have been met and that they can be evidenced to an EPA organisation. Apprentices must complete a portfolio of work evidencing their knowledge, skills and behaviours in support of the Professional Discussion prior to taking their EPA. Painter and Decorator Apprentices without English and Mathematics at level 2 must achieve level 1 English and Mathematics and take the tests for level 2 prior to taking their EPA for Painting and Decorating Level 2 Apprenticeship.

The primary role of the Teaching Assistant is to support the class teacher to enhance pupils' learning either in groups or individually, ensuring pupils understand the work set, know their learning objectives and stay on task in order to make progress. Promoting self-belief, social inclusion and a high self-esteem play an integral part to pupils' well-being; ensuring pupils thrive in a positive, nurturing, safe environment. It is an active role supporting the learner to access the curriculum. They are good role models, act with honesty and integrity, take part in team meetings; contribute to planning and class activities.

Progression to Gateway will take place in month 21. The employer will confirm that the Apprentice has: 1. completed the portfolio to the required standards and entries have been validated by that employer. 2. A current DBS Certificate. 3. Achieved the mandatory qualification 4. Achieved level 2 in maths and English or equivalent (if not already previously achieved). Progress to Gateway and End Point Assessment only takes place when the employer, learner and the provider agree that they are ready to progress to end point assessment (EPA). During the Gateway stage the learner will be supported in EPA practice and mock tests and professional discussions.

Skilled in recognising and assessing the complex needs that children, young people and families often present, you will agree with the child, young person or family any specific interventions or referrals.
OPTION 1: Practitioner in Children's Residential Care of the Standard.
Apprentices could be working in a number of settings e.g. a children’s home, a residential special school or a secure children’s home. The children might be living on their own or in a larger group. The Apprentice will need to take the lead in developing and delivering the child's placement plan and will work with the child to support their health, education, social and day to day needs, playing a significant role in helping them to thrive and fulfil their potential.

Beauty Professional- Beauty Therapy. This apprenticeship will provide you with the following skills and knowledge, waxing treatments, hand and nail treatments, foot treatments, facial treatments, eyelash and eyebrow treatments, make-up application, basic massage treatments. You will also develop industry behaviours which will allow you to work in the Hair and Beauty/Nail industry effectively

Beauty Professional- Nail services technician. This apprenticeship will provide you with the following skills, advice to customers on nail products and services, manicure services, pedicure services, gel polish services, basic nail art services and nail enhancement systems. You will also develop industry behaviours which will allow you to work in the Hair and Beauty/Nail industry effectively.

Horticulture and Landscape Supervisors can be employed to oversee work in public parks and gardens, green spaces and historic gardens, private gardens and estates or in production nurseries and retail outlets. Many businesses will be specialised in their activities, such as grounds maintenance (soft-landscape) or landscape construction (hard-landscape). Soft-landscaping includes the establishment and maintenance of plants and cultivated areas. Hard-landscaping includes establishment of hard surfaces and structures in addition to the establishment of plants in cultivated areas. You may also manage a site with minimum supervision, supervise a team and maintain the health and safety and security of personnel and resources.

*   The Assessor Coach will coach and assess apprentices, trainees or new recruits in the workplace, commensurate with their own level of experience and qualifications, as required by their employer or their sector. 
*   They coach and assess vocational learners, usually on a one-to-one basis, in a range of learning environments.
*   Coaching skills involve complex communication techniques to actively listen, provide feedback and to engage learners in planning their individualised learning programme.
*   These skills are also integral to assessing learners' competence in-relation to work-related/industry standards and life skills.
*   They give practical, technical and/or pastoral support and guidance.

Learning Mentors support learners of all ages, and all levels, to develop within a new work role, these learners may be, apprentices, trainees or new recruits.

They have sector-specific experience, up-to-date knowledge and skills in a specialist vocational or subject area with a relevant vocational qualification.

Learning Mentors guide and advise those who are less experienced and new to a work role and support the development of learners' knowledge, skills and behaviours.

They give practical, technical and/or pastoral support and guidance.

Apprentices typically take 18 mths completing their on-programme requirements before progressing to Gateway. This includes evidencing that the apprentice has met the minimum 20% off-the-job learning, achieved the Diploma for the Children and Young People’s Workforce: Early Years Educator, completed the showcase portfolio, achieved a minimum of Level 2 mathematics and English, and a Level 3 Award in Paediatric First Aid (RQF) as stated in the |Standard and as per the EYFS requirements. Progress to Gateway and End Point Assessment only takes place when the employer, learner and the provider agree that they are ready to progress. During the Gateway stage the learner will be supported in EPA practice and mock tests and professional discussions.

An Accounts/Finance Assistant is an integral part of the team responsible for maintaining an efficient and accurate finance function within a business. The Accounts/Finance Assistant is responsible for assisting the team of accountants with junior accounting duties. These can vary massively depending on the team structure and size of business. An Accounts/Finance Assistant’s work could include basic bookkeeping activities, working with sales and purchase ledgers, running calculations to ensure that records and payments are correct, recording of cash and data entry. Accounts/Finance Assistants can work in almost any sector.

Advanced apprenticeship Creative Hair Professionals. (stylist). This apprenticeship will provide you with the following skills and knowledge, Provide client consultation services, Creatively style and dress hair, Creatively cut hair using a combination of techniques, Creatively colour and lighten hair, Hair colour correction services, straightening and smoothing systems, use fashion forward trends to create a collection. You will also develop industry behaviours which will allow you to work in the Hair and Beauty industry effectively.

Early Years Practitioners work directly with children on a day to day basis supporting in planning and delivery of activities, play and educational programmes. An EYP works as part of a team ensuring the welfare and care for children under the guidance and supervision of an Early Years Educator, teacher or other qualified professional. They may work in a range of private and public settings including; full day care, children’s centres, pre-schools, reception classes, playgroups, hospitals and home based, social care, out of school or local authority provision to deliver the Early Years Foundation Stage (EYFS) requirements for the learning, development and care of children from birth to 5 in both indoor and outdoor environments.

Lead Practitioner in Adult Care will guide and inspire team members to make positive differences to someone’s life when they are faced with physical, practical, social, emotional, psychological or intellectual challenges. Lead Practitioners have a greater depth of knowledge and expertise of particular conditions experienced by the user of services. They have specialist skills and knowledge which will allow them to lead in areas such as care assessments, physiotherapy, OT, rehabilitation and enablement, telecare and assistive technology. They will coach and mentor others and have a role in assessing performance and quality of care delivery. They work in residential, nursing, clinical, domiciliary settings, day centres or a person’s own home.

name: THE TRAINING INITIATIVE GROUP LTD
marketingInfo:
The Training Initiative is based in Tamworth, Staffordshire and is a specialist training provider of Health & Social Care, Warehousing, Fitness and Security apprenticeships. We work with providers throughout the country to deliver staff training ranging from mandatory courses through to specialist training sessions.  

Our training team comprises of industry professionals who support an apprentice's understanding through a range of methods including practical application and in-depth professional discussion.  

We work with employers and apprentices to ensure all programmes of study are planned effectively to ensure both are supported throughout the apprenticeship delivery.

name: THE WEST MIDLANDS CREATIVE ALLIANCE LIMITED
tradingName: THE WEST MIDLANDS CREATIVE ALLIANCE LIMITED
marketingInfo:
Creative Alliance is an independent learning provider within the creative and cultural sector. We enable talented young people to get into creative, digital or marketing roles regardless of background or previous education. We do this by:  

* Creative careers education and employability skills programmes  
* Creative apprenticeships and traineeships  
* Start-up support for creative businesses  

Creative Alliance is a social enterprise founded in 2005\. We have delivered apprenticeships in the Creative Sector since 2009\. We are Matrix Accredited for the quality of advice and guidance and have been recognised for our training delivery including an award from the Social Enterprise UK award winners 2015 for education, training and jobs.

standards.marketingInfo:
The primary role of a software developer is to build and test simple, high-quality code across front end, logic, and database layers. A developer will typically be working as part of a larger team, in which they will have responsibility for some of the straightforward elements of the overall project. The developer will need to be able to interpret design documentation and specifications.

Our work-based training is based around your workplace and the job they are being paid to do! Training throughout the 18 apprenticeships will include:

  • BCS Systems Development Essentials
  • Microsoft Certification: MTA/MCP programming in HTML5 with Javascript and CSS3
  • Working on assignments 
  • Mentoring support for projects
  • Practical training with development coaches

A digital marketer will typically be working as part of a team, in which they will have responsibility for some of the straightforward elements of the overall marketing plan or campaign. The marketer will work to marketing briefs and instructions. 

Our work-based training is based around your workplace and the job they are being paid to do! Typically training throughout the apprenticeship will include:

  • Classroom or online seminars
  • Projects tailored around your workplace
  • Working on project assignments
  • CIW Vendor Qualification
  • BCS principles of Coding
  • Mentoring support for projects
  • Practical training with development coaches

Digital Marketer Standard can be delivered remotley or with classroom sessions at our training academy in Birmingham

Team Leader/Supervisor standard is for individuals looking for a career in leadership and management and want to take the first step into developing these skills and starting out in professional management. Apprentices will develop the knowledge and skills to support, manage, develop team members, manage projects. The training will enable apprentices to start planning and monitoring resources, deliver operational plans and build relationships. 

Our work-based training is based around your workplace and the job they are being paid to do! Training throughout the 15-month apprenticeship includes:

  • Ten classroom or online seminars
  • Working on assignments
  • Mentoring support for projects
  • Practical training with development coaches

Broadcast Production Assistant Standard covers a variety of roles with different levels of activity and responsibility typically working within a team of people or in departments within a production company or other media sectors such as radio and post-production. A Broadcast Production Assistant is a junior position working across radio, television, film, and within post-production facility companies and can cover a range of activities.

Our work-based training is based around your workplace and the job they are being paid to do! Training throughout the apprenticeship 15-month apprenticeship will include:

  • Classroom or online seminars 
  • Working on assignments 
  • Mentoring support for projects
  • Practical training with development coaches

Customer Service Specialist develops the knowledge skills and behaviours for apprentice's working in many types of businesses. Apprentice's will demonstrate excellent customer service skills as well as product and/or service knowledge when delivering to your customers. We offer a work-based learning model, and deliver training and assessment using a blended learning approach.

This can include:

*   The teaching of theory
*   Principles of the creative and cultural sector
*   Working on assignments for their portfolio
*   Mentoring support with assignments and projects
*   Practical training with dedicated development coaches
*   Time spent writing assessments and assignments

Customer Service practitioner standard is 15 months.

The Project Management Apprenticeship is designed to prepare an apprentice for an associate project manager role. Skills provided as part of the apprenticeship include:

*   Project Governance
*   Budgeting and Cost Control
*   Consolidated Planning
*   Business Case and Benefits
*   Quality Management
*   Stakeholder and Communications Management

As part of the apprenticeship programme it is expected that the project manager will be able to demonstrate behaviour's such as:

*   Collaboration and Teamwork
*   Leadership
*   Integrity, Ethics, Compliance and Professionalism

Event assistant standard develops the skills knowledge and behaviours apprentice require to support to an event such as conferences, productions, meetings, trade shows and exhibitions. Typically assisting project managers by assisting with, planning of an event, organise and deliver an event, working with design teams, logistics like transportation and catering.

We offer a work-based learning model, this can include:

*   The teaching of theory
*   Working on assignments for their portfolio
*   Mentoring support with assignments and projects
*   Practical training with dedicated development coaches
*   Time spent writing assessments and assignments

Events assistant standard duration is between 15 and 18 months.

Junior Content Producer standard develops the knowledge and skills to create content that can be used across a variety of media including digital, social media, broadcast, or in print. Apprentices work to customer/client brief, research, prepare and develop the media messaging to maximise audience engagement. The content they create can be used as part of media, advertising, and marketing campaigns.

Our work-based training is based around your workplace and the job they are being paid to do! Typically training throughout the apprenticeship will include:

Fourteen classroom or online seminars
Projects tailored around your workplace.
Working on project assignments
Mentoring support for projects
Practical training with development coaches

The Business Administrator apprenticeship develops and provides a highly transferable set of knowledge, skills, and behaviors, which can be gained working across an organisation and its processes. The apprenticeship is a firm grounding in organisational operations and functional processes, as well as the wider working environment. Key responsibilities include developing, implementing, maintaining, and improving administrative services.

Our work-based training is based around your workplace and the job they are being paid to do! Training throughout the apprenticeship will include:

  • Fourteen classroom or online seminars 
  • Working on assignments 
  • Mentoring support for projects
  • Practical training with development coaches
  • Time spent on assignments

Creative Venue Technicians provide technical support for the construction, rehearsal, presentation and removal of a live performance, for audience or camera. A Creative Venue Technician will play an active role in the technical operation across a variety of established creative venues, for example, theatres, arts centres and broadcast studios. We offer a work-based learning model, and deliver training and assessment using a blended learning approach.

This can include:

*   The teaching of theory
*   Working on assignments for their portfolio
*   Mentoring support with assignments and projects
*   Practical training with dedicated development coaches
*   Time spent writing assessments and assignments

Creative Venue Technician standard is between 18 and 24 months.

Customer Service Specialist develops the knowledge skills and behaviours for apprentice's working in contact centres, creative businesses, theatre or cultural venues. The purpose of a customer service specialist is to be a ‘professional’ for direct customer support within all sectors and organisations. Apprentices will develop the skills to provide high-quality customer service becoming experts in your organisation's services.

Our work-based training is based around your workplace and the job they are being paid to do! Training throughout the apprenticeship will include:

  • Fifteen classroom or online seminars 
  • Working on assignments 
  • Mentoring support for projects
  • Practical training with development coaches
  • Time spent on assignments

A Marketing Executive standard will help shape, support, and deliver marketing plans. A highly audience-focused role that requires creativity, communication, and project management skills - with responsibilities for planning and executing tactical and targeted marketing activity.

Our work-based training is based around your workplace and the job they are being paid to do! Typically training throughout the 15-18 month apprenticeship will include:

  • 10 classroom or online seminars 
  • Working on assignments for their portfolio
  • Mentoring support for projects
  • Practical training with development coaches
  • Time spent on assignments

Cultural Learning and Participation (CLPO) Officers plan, organise and co-ordinate artistic and cultural education workshops, schedules of activity and community engagement projects. The activities that are planned, organised and co-ordinated by the CLPO, typically include teaching arts, culture and heritage subjects, creative workshops, visits, talks, performances, festivals, events and digital arts, using online content

Our work-based training is based around your workplace and the job they are being paid to do! Training throughout the apprenticeship will include:

  • Classroom or online seminars
  • Projects tailored around your workplace
  • Working on project assignments
  • Mentoring support for projects
  • Practical training with development coaches

address.address1: UNIT 213-216 SCOTT HOUSE, THE CUSTARD FACTORY

name: LONDON SOUTH EAST COLLEGES
marketingInfo:
The London South East Apprenticeship Company is highly experienced in placing Apprentices with the right employers and getting people back into meaningful employment. Apprenticeships lead to growth and regeneration and give local people the chance to work in their own communities.

If you are an employer, taking on an Apprentice means that you are investing in your staff as well as keeping up-to-date with the advances in technology and innovative working methods. We will ensure that our recruitment process involves thorough criteria checks prior to introducing you to an applicant. We will work with you to provide flexible training that is developed primarily in your workplace enabling you to fully develop your staff to help your business.

standards.marketingInfo: The primary role of a Property Maintenance Operative is to optimise property condition and quality and to ensure the building is kept in a safe working condition. Property Maintenance Operatives need to maintain a high level of quality, providing maximum satisfaction to customers, clients, guests and team. They will understand the mechanism of buildings including electrical, plumbing, plant, safety systems and equipment. They will provide first and immediate response to fault finding, whilst maximising quality and ensuring cost effectiveness. They will ensure prevention of major damage that could result in extensive costs and minimise reactive intervention

LSEC deliver motor vehicle service and maintenance technician services and repairs light vehicles, 36 month delivery at the college. The Automotive Retail Industry provides employment for over half a million employees who work for approximately 70,000 employers. It is a major contributor to the UK economy. In a large dealership the Technician will typically report to the Workshop Controller, who in turn reports to the Aftersales Manager and liaises with the Service Reception. In smaller garages the Technician will report directly to the owner or Garage Manager.

The Dental Nurse role complements the role of other dental professionals. One of the primary roles is to provide chair side support to dental professionals and deliver a high level of patient care. Dental Nurses may work in a variety of clinical environments and the Apprenticeship reflects all aspects of clinical responsibilities and duties of a dental nurse's role and will provide the apprentice with the relevant qualification to apply to the General Dental Council (GDC) for professional registration as a dental nurse.

The primary role of a digital marketer is to define, design, build and implement digital campaigns across a variety of online and social media platforms to drive customer acquisition, customer engagement and customer retention. A digital marketer will typically be working as part of a team, in which they will have responsibility for some of the straightforward elements of the overall marketing plan or campaign. The marketer will work to marketing briefs and instructions. They will normally report to a digital marketing manager, a marketing manager or an IT Manager.

The primary role of a Data Analyst is to collect, organise and study data to provide business insight. Data analysts are typically involved with managing, cleansing, abstracting and aggregating data, and conducting a range of analytical studies on that data. They work across a variety of projects, providing technical data solutions to a range of stakeholders/customers issues. They document and report the results of data analysis activities making recommendations to improve business performance.

An Infrastructure Technician provides support to internal and external customers, helping them to be productive when using technology to do their own jobs, by using tools to problem solve and trouble shoot non routine problems. The Infrastructure Technician sets people up on systems and provides support when they need it, rectifying issues to maintain the organisations productivity. Typical roles: Help Desk Technician, First or Second Line Support, IT Infrastructure Technician, Network Support ### Individual employers will set the selection criteria, include five GCSEs, (especially English, Mathematics and a Science or Technology subject); other relevant qualifications and experience; or an aptitude test with a focus on IT skills.

Working as a commis chef is a great way of getting started in a kitchen; while it’s the most junior culinary role it provides a means of learning a range of key skills on the job. A commis chef prepares food and carries out basic cooking tasks under the supervision of a more senior chef. A primary objective of the commis chef is to learn and understand how tocarry out the basic functions in every section of the kitchen. This gives them the opportunity to experience, consider and value each section with a view to choosing an area where they feel most inspired.

A hospitality team member can work in a range of establishments, for example bars, restaurants, cafés, conference centres, banqueting venues, hotels or contract caterers. The role is very varied and although hospitality team members tend to specialise in an area, they have to be adaptable and ready to support team members across the business, for example during busy periods. Specialist areas in hospitality include food and beverage service, serving alcoholic beverages, barista, food preparation, housekeeping, concierge and guest services, reception, reservations and conference and banqueting. The most important part of the role is developing fantastic 'hospitality' skills and knowledge such as recognising customer needs.

LSEC is working with Mindful to deliver a blend learning platform, we have mapped in CMI Level 5 diploma throughout our programme. We are running monthly workshops at our campuses. An operations/departmental manager is someone who manages teams and/or projects, and achieving operational or departmental goals and objectives, as part of the delivery of the organisation's strategy. They are accountable to a more senior manager or a business owner. Working in the private, public or third sector and in all sizes of organisation, specific responsibilities and job titles will vary, but the knowledge, skills and behaviours needed.

LSEC is working with Mindful to deliver a blend learning platform, we have mapped in CMI Level 3 diploma throughout our programme. We are running monthly workshops at our campuses. A team leader/supervisor is a first-line management role, with operational/project responsibilities or responsibility for managing a team to deliver a clearly defined outcome. They provide direction, instructions and guidance to ensure the achievement of set goals. Working in the private, public or third sector and in all sizes of organisation, specific responsibilities will vary, but the knowledge, skills and behaviours needed will be the same whatever the role.

LSEC is working with Mindful to deliver a blend learning platform, we have mapped in CMI Level 3 diploma throughout our programme. We are running monthly workshops at our campuses. A team leader/supervisor is a first-line management role, with operational/project responsibilities or responsibility for managing a team to deliver a clearly defined outcome. They provide direction, instructions and guidance to ensure the achievement of set goals. Working in the private, public or third sector and in all sizes of organisation, specific responsibilities will vary, but the knowledge, skills and behaviours needed will be the same whatever the role.

Lead Adult Care Workers are the front line staff who help adults with care and support needs to achieve their personal goals and live as independently and safely as possible, enabling them to have control and choice in their lives. In addition, Lead Adult Care Workers have responsibility for providing supervision, frontline leadership, guidance and direction for others, or working autonomously, exercising judgement and accountability.

Typical job titles include:

  • Care Officer
  • Care Supervisor
  • Senior Care Worker
  • Supervising Care Worker
  • Senior Support Worker
  • Relief Team Leader
  • Social Work Assistant

Adult Care Workers are the frontline staff who help adults with care and support needs to achieve their personal goals and live as independently and safely as possible, enabling them to have control and choice in their lives. Job titles might include: Care Assistant, Care Worker, Support Worker, Personal Assistant, Relief Team Worker, Support Worker - Supported Living, Key Worker in Residential Settings, Key Worker in Domiciliary Services, Key Worker in Day Services, Home Care Support Worker, Substance Misuse Worker, Learning Disability Support Worker, Mental Health Support Worker, Mental Health Outreach Worker and Re-enablement Worker. Monthly Workshops, one to one visits on the employer site.

The role of a customer service practitioner is to deliver high quality products and services to the customers of their organisation. Your core responsibility will be to provide a high quality service to customers which will be delivered from the workplace, digitally, or through going out into the customer's own locality. These may be one-off or routine contacts and include dealing with orders, payments, offering advice, guidance and support, meet-and-greet, sales, fixing problems, after care, service recovery or gaining insight through measuring customer satisfaction. You may be the first point of contact and work in any sector or organisation type.

Projects can be defined and delivered within different contexts, across diverse industry sectors. They can be large or small. Every project needs to be managed to ensure its success, An associate project manager knows what needs to be achieved, how it will be achieved, how long it will take and how much it will cost, and works with the project team to achieve the required outcomes. Associate project managers need good planning, organisation, leadership, management and communication skills. An associate project manager utilises resources with suitable skills, qualifications, experience and knowledge to work together in a motivated and integrated team, with clearly defined reporting lines, roles, responsibilities and authorities.

An Assistant Accountant provides support to internal and external customers and will work predominately either as an assistant accountant within practice or alternatively within the finance function of an organisation. Part of their role will involve assisting in the day to day financial activities such as data entry to month end management accounts and/or year-end financial statements. In addition the Assistant Accountant may find themselves involved in regulatory financial requirements such as the completion of VAT returns or assisting in the preparation of tax computations.

Hospitality supervisors work across a wide variety of
businesses including bars, restaurants, cafés, conference
centres, banqueting venues, hotels or contract caterers.
They provide vital support to management teams and
are capable of independently supervising hospitality
services and running shifts, so the ability to think on their
feet is important. They typically work well under pressure
de-livering top-class customer service, and the ability to
motivate a team is essential to their role. The core set of
supervisors’ skills and knowledge are the same regardless
of the setting, but super-visors may specialise in specific
functions or work across a variety of areas of the business
reflecting the multifunctional nature of the industry.

There are two distinctly different job roles within this occupational profile: Hairdresser and Barber. Hairdressers will be able to shampoo and condition hair, cut hair using a range of techniques, style and finish hair to create variety of looks, and colour and lighten hair for ladies and men. Barbers will be able to shampoo and condition hair, cut hair using barbering techniques, style and finish hair, cut facial hair into shape and provide shaving services for men. Hairdressers and barbers must be able to work with all hair types ranging from straight hair to very curly, wiry hair, demonstrate the professionalism, values, behaviours, communication skills and safe working practices.

Engineering Technicians in the Aerospace, Aviation, Automotive, Maritime Defence and wider Advanced Manufacturing and Engineering Sector are predominantly involved in highly skilled, complex work and must, as a minimum be able to:

Engineering Technicians take responsibility for the quality and accuracy of the work they undertake within the limits of their personal authority. They also need to be able to demonstrate a core set of behaviours in order to be competent in their job role, complement wider business strategy and development. This will enable them to support their long term career development.

HR Consultant or an HR Business Partner in different organisations. Individuals in this role will use their HR expertise to provide and lead the delivery of HR solutions to business challenges, together with tailored advice to the business in a number of HR areas, typically to mid-level and senior managers. They could be in a generalist role, where they provide support across a range of HR areas - likely to be the Core HR option; or a specialist role, where they focus on and have in depth expertise in a specific area of HR - likely to be Resourcing, Total Reward, Organisation Development, or HR Operations and whole range of HR disciplines as this is contained in both of the qualification options included in this standard.

HR Professionals in this role are typically either working in a medium to large organisation as part of the HR function delivering front line support to managers and employees, or are a HR Manager in a small organisation. Their work is likely to include handling day to day queries and providing HR advice; working on a range of HR processes, ranging from transactional to relatively complex, from recruitment through to retirement; using HR systems to keep records; providing relevant HR information to the business; working with the business on HR changes. They will typically be taking ownership for providing advice to managers on a wide range of HR issues using company policy and current law, giving guidance that is compliant.

Business administrators have a highly transferable set of knowledge, skills and behaviours that can be applied in all sectors. This includes small and large businesses alike; from the public sector, private sector and charitable sector. The role may involve working independently or as part of a team and will involve developing, implementing, maintaining and improving administrative services. Business administrators develop key skills and behaviours to support their own progression towards management responsibilities. The responsibilities of the role are to support and engage with different parts of the organisation and interact with internal or external customers.

The Level 6  Teachers’ Standard, the apprentices will be awarded Qualified Teacher Status (QTS). The apprentice will also need to demonstrate the knowledge, skills and behaviours contained within the Teachers’ Standards during their end-point assessment.
During the apprenticeship programme, the apprentice must successfully complete a programme of Initial Teacher Training and be awarded QTS by the TRA/DfE. Individual providers of ITE accredited by the NCTL or DfE, retain the responsibility for making the professional judgement as to whether each apprentice has demonstrated the range of knowledge, skills and understanding required to be recommended for Qualified Teacher Status (QTS), in line with current Initial Teacher Training practice.

The occupation involves carrying out skilled work, primarily using timber products, either on a construction site or in a workshop, creating and installing building components.  A Site Carpenter will normally work on a building site, or in domestic and commercial premises, preparing and fixing building components, from the initial erection of a new building, through to the installationof all necessary fixtures and fittings, as well as a range of repair andmaintenance activities.

The advanced carpenter and joiner are able to undertake complex job tasks, requiring high levels of practical skills and knowledge, in addition to managing their own work and leading small teams. The main differences between a level 2 site carpenter / architectural joiner, and a level 3 advanced site carpenter / architectural joiner are that the advanced carpenter/joiner has responsibility for managing their own and other people's work, as well as being required to complete complex and non-standard work. Examples of complex tasks include curved products, irregular joints and bespoke work.

CSS equips learners with the knowledge to deal with complex or demanding customer complaints, queries, or requests. Learners will develop a customer-centric approach and will look to influence positive change in processes and overall customer service within the company. Apprentices will focus on their knowledge of the customer journey with a view to developing a deeper insight into their customers’ needs and wants. Individuals will work on the skills needed to provide a positive customer experience. The learners will cover some of the following during their apprenticeship: continuous improvement in a service environment; customer service culture and environment awareness; managing difficult situations, and delivering positive solutions.

Bricklayers lay bricks, blocks and other types of building components in mortar to construct and repair walls, foundations, partitions, arches and other structures eg chimney stacks. They might also refurbish brickwork and masonry on restoration projects. The range of sites and projects that bricklayers will work on include large commercial developments, new builds in housing, alterations, extensions and restorations. A bricklayer may work one-on-one or on larger jobs where their bricklaying group (gang) may work on a particular section of a building alongside other bricklaying gangs as well as other trades.

Teaching Assistants work in Primary, Special and Secondary education across all age ranges encompassing special educational needs and emotional vulnerabilities. The primary role of the Teaching Assistant is to support the class teacher to enhance pupils' learning either in groups or individually, ensuring pupils understand the work set, know their learning objectives and stay on task in order to make progress. Promoting self-belief, social inclusion and a high self-esteem play an integral part to pupils' well-being; ensuring pupils thrive in a positive, nurturing, safe environment. It is an active role supporting the learner to access the curriculum.

This engineering operative apprenticeship is specifically designed for those who work in the manufacturing sector such as production and/or process workers, stores or material handlers, quality and production supervisors.  The role of an engineering operative covers a wide range of common and job-specific skills sets that can be transferred across the manufacturing engineering industry sectors during the course of their careers.  LSEC will cover the following: Identify and deal appropriately with any risks, hazards, hazardous situations and problems that may occur within the engineering environment.

Mandatory qualifications:  

Level 2 Diploma in engineering operations(skills)

Level 2 Certificate or Diploma in engineering operations (knowledge)

Production chefs work as part of a team in time-bound and often challenging kitchen environments, for example; schools, hospitals, the Armed Forces, care homes and high street casual dining or pub kitchens. They report to the Senior Production chef or appropriate line manager. Production chefs are likely to work with centrally developed standardised recipes and menus, producing food often in high volumes. They apply highly methodical organisational skills, energy, accuracy, attention to detail and are mindful of the importance of sustainability and protecting the environment. Production chefs; * maintain excellent standards of personal, food and kitchen hygiene * ensure compliance to procedures, menu specifications and recipes.

Social Work is an exciting and fulfilling international profession. As a Social Worker you will work in partnership with adults, children, carers and families in a range of different settings to support and promote positive change in people's lives in order to improve their wellbeing and independence.  Within the context of relevant Social Work legislation, you will use your professional judgement and build relationships with a variety of individuals and communities, as well as with a wide range of other professionals and agencies. In your role you will assess, plan, implement and evaluate complex situations. This requires an ability to critically reflect and make decisions within a clear professional code of ethics.

Groundworkers are the first trade onto a construction and civil engineering site and they work closely with supervisors and engineers in interpreting design specifications to prepare the site ready for the structural building works to take place. They continue their work throughout the construction phase, working with all on-site construction trades, such as bricklayers and plant operatives, up to and including the final completion activities of the project. Their work includes setting out and preparing the sub-surfaces ready for the structural work to begin, installing drainage systems, concreting, constructing roads and pathways and carrying out the finished hard landscaping.

LSEC is delivering the Assessor Coach Apprenticeship, AC offers an up-to-date professional knowledge and skills to support vocational and professional development across the formal ETS as well as in any employer setting, and at any level. Coaching skills involve complex communication techniques to actively listen, provide feedback and to engage learners in planning their individualised learning programme. 

The employer is the major stakeholder in our apprenticeship programmes, London South East College works closely with the employer to offer a flexible approach.

The Learning and Skills Teacher (LST) is ‘dual-professional’, having first achieved competence in a vocational or subject specialism and then subsequently trained as a teacher.  This means that many teachers in the Education and Training Sector (ETS) begin teaching as a second, or even later, career.  LSTs are responsible for planning and delivering learning that is current, relevant, challenging, and that inspires learners to engage and achieve their full potential. 

The employer is the major stakeholder in our apprenticeship programmes, London South East College works closely with the employer to offer a flexible approach.

LMs support learners of all ages, and all levels, to develop within a new work role.  These learners may be, for example, apprentices, trainees or new recruits (ranging from young entrants, to new CEOs) in the workplace, or in any vocational learning environment. Learning Mentors will have sector-specific experience and qualifications, as determined by their employer or professional body, which they use to guide and advise those who are less experienced and new to a work role.

Early Years Educators, and other job roles such as nursery nurse and childminders, are highly trained professionals who play a key role in ensuring that young children learn and develop well and are kept healthy and safe. They work in a range of settings including full day care, children's centres, pre schools, reception classes and as childminders. They may either be working on their own or supervising others to deliver the Early Years Foundation Stage (EYFS) requirements set by Government for the learning, development and care of children from birth to 5 years old.

The occupation covered by this standard is Construction Quantity Surveying Technician. * Assisting senior managers with the budgeting of construction projects * Control of costs during a construction project * Selection and management of specialist contractors * To contribute to the mitigation of disputes using accurate records * Recording, control and reporting of income and expenditure on a construction project * Valuation of progress on construction projects * To assist senior managers with the legal and contractual issues on a construction project

An Accounts/Finance Assistant is an integral part of the team responsible for maintaining an efficient and accurate finance function within a business. LSEC will cover the following through monthly workshops at the college, aware of elements of commercial law that may have an impact when working in accountancy, such as contracts, data protection or Anti Money Laundering and can explain the importance of upholding relevant codes of conduct as well as explain different legal entities and organisational structures.

An EYP will also support the observation and assessment of each child and contribute to their learning experiences and assist with the care needs of the individual child such as teeth, skin, hair, feeding, changing nappies and toileting under the direction of a more senior member of the team. They will also work in partnerships with other colleagues, parents and/or carers or other professionals, with support from a more senior member of the team, to meet the individual needs of each child. They will also have a responsibility for ensuring that they recognise when a child is in danger and/or at risk of serious harm or abuse and contributing to the health and safety of the children, staff and others on the premises.
